title: What apps should parents be on the lookout for on their teens’ phones? - Quora

response.answer_text: I sorry if your thinking like Journie Nabors. But trying to leash your kids with technology isnt going to work, and is in fact rather counter productive. The first person that asked me how to bypass their parents use of Life 360 was right here on quora I answered by pointed them to a first page result on how to spoof my phones GPS. Disclaimer: I’m a highly opinionated childless know it all. I have a negative opinion of this as a parental strategy. But that is independent of my assessment of the technical aspects of parental controls. But I’ve worked enough IT/IT security to know that despite the promises made by the people who make and sell the stuff, parental spy/malware is at best just security theater. At first it all look and sounds all good. Until the day comes that your teen decides that its an obstacle that they need to get around. There is an internet full of people (including me) who are more then happy to help them slip their digital leash. If they want it bad enough they will find a way. A cinder-block wall costs $80/foot and takes weeks to build, a ladder cost $20 and can be there in an hour. Its the same nature of defense vs attack applies to software as well. Near infinite possibilities that need to be defended against, attacker just needs to find or make one whole. … How does one set up parental control on kid's phones and computers? Now that isn't to say that you cant have transparency and accountability for your children and their devices. Its possible to be able to locate them when needed, its just not possible to be able to locate them 24/7/365. You can have the visibility to guide and protect them, you just can’t randomly comb trough the intimate details of their lives. You can be a dictator and do irreparable damage to your kids and your relationship as you attempt to strip them of their boundaries. Or you can be a decent human being and responsible parent. Me personally, I’m with Christian Krueger, I want to someday know my grandchildren. How do I convince my mom not to put spying software on my phone?

The sheriff's office, and most recently the Madill Police Department in Oklahoma, shared graphics showing 15 apps parents should know about. The apps include well-known social media and dating apps like Snapchat, TikTok and WhatsApp, as well as location-based dating apps like MeetMe, Grindr and Skout. Here’s the top 15: MeetMe: A dating social media app that connects people based on location. Users are encouraged to meet in person.WhatsApp: A messaging app that allows texts, video calls, photo sharing and voicemails with users worldwide.Bumble: Similar to Tinder, but requires women to make the first contact. Law enforcement says kids and teens can create fake accounts and falsify their age.Twitch: A live-streaming app that uses geolocation to share videos. The sheriff's office said users can earn "coins" to "pay" minors for photos.Ask and Answer - ASKfm: The sheriff's office said this app lets users ask anonymous questions and is known for cyberbullying.Grindr: A dating app geared toward the LGBTQ community based on user location.TikTok: A new app popular with kids lets users create and share short videos. Law enforcement said the app has "very limited privacy controls" and users can be exposed to cyberbullying and explicit content.Snapchat: One of the most popular social media apps in the world, Snapchat lets users take and share photos and videos. The app also lets people see your location.Holla: This self-proclaimed "addicting" video chat app lets users meet people in seconds. Law enforcement said users have seen racial slurs and explicit content.Calculator+: Police say this is one of several apps that are used to hide photos, videos, files and browser history.Skout: A location-based dating app that is supposed to prohibit people under 17 from sharing private photos. However, police say kids can easily create an account with a different age.Badoo: A dating and social media app where users can chat and share photos and videos based on location. Police say the app is supposed to be for adults only, but they've seen teens create accounts.Kik: Police say kids can bypass traditional text messaging features using this app. Kik "gives users unlimited access to anyone, anywhere, anytime," the sheriff's office said.Whisper: An anonymous social network that lets users share secrets with strangers. Police say it also shows users' location so people can meet up.Hot or Not: The app lets users rate profiles, check out people in their area and chat with strangers. Police say the goal of the app is to hook up.Don’t over-react if you find any of these Apps on your child’s phone. It is a status symbol to have access to them and a Right of Passage to use them. Just be vigilant and occasionally tell them stories about your friends’ kids [make them up if you have to] who got in serious danger when they gave out too much personal information to strangers using one of these Apps.
